roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: We'll hear argument first this morning in Number oh oh five oh seven, the Chickasaw Nation versus the United States.
Mr. Luthey.
[Inaudible]
Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court.
The Chickasaw and Choctaw Nations ask this Court to hold that Congress has afforded tribes the same exemption from Federal wagering taxes enjoyed by State governmental wagering operations.

We do not base our claim on policy untethered to statutory text, but instead we bla- base our claim today on section twenty D of the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act codified at twenty-five USC, section twenty-seven nineteen D.

Unfortunately, for all concerned, that statutory text is ambiguous, as every appellate judge which has examined it has held either expressly or implicitly, and as we expect the Government to admit today if the question is put to them.

One of the possible constructions of that ambiguous statute, based on its text and structure and giving effect to every word of the statute and bolstered by its legislative history, is that the tax exemption afforded States by Internal Revenue Code chapter thirty-five, expressly referenced in section twenty-seven nineteen D, applies equally to tribal wagering operations.
[Inaudible]

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Where do we find this exact text that you're talking about in the brief or in...
I would direct Your Honor to the petitioner's appendix ninety A,
to our appendix for certiorari.
Well, haven't you set it out on...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: page three?
Yes, sir.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: On page three of your brief? That's a handier reference I think if,

Now starting with the actual text of the statute, we believe that the statute contains two central textual commands, one that has to do with the reporting and withholding of taxes from gaming, from wei- from the winnings from gaming, and also the application of the Internal Revenue Code provisions concerning wagering operations.
to apply...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: before you proceed further with this argument that you make in your reply brief, did you present it, this or distinguishing gaming on the one hand from wagering operations? Did you present that to the Tenth Circuit?
Not directly like that, Your Honor, we did not.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And did you present it in your opening brief?
What we did, Your Honor, in the opening brief is adopt the decision by the majority in the Little Six decision from the...
Federal circuit.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: make this argument.
No.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, you've answered the question.
To address specifically, Your Honor, the Government's position which we claim is based on a false premise.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: That was not a new position.
The way we would have the provision read, Your Honor, is set out at page nine.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Page what?
Page nine of the reply brief where we suggest that concerning addresses two distinct central textual commands...
in in...
in contradiction, Your Honor, to the Government's assertion that there is one central...
textual command.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: and you would say that the way to read it is, concerning the re- t- the way it reads, if one would read it normally, is, concerning the reporting and withholding of taxes with respect to the winnings from gaming or wagering operations.
Your Honor, if I could...
respond.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I wish you would.
I th- I think our reading is informed by the parenthetical reference that precedes these two concepts, and particularly the text and structure of that parenthetical reference.
that. The govern-

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: the winnings from wagering.
From gaming.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But not from wagering.
Yeah, it's from gaming by players, Your Honor.
of the parenthetical...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I thought that gaming, a gaming operations or wagering operations, perhaps you can clarify what is the difference between gaming as a noun and wagering operations?
I- It's our, a- and you hit hit right exactly on the point, Your Honor.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But not the winnings by players from wagering.
No.
And and what...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

I- the the difference is how it is used in the context of this statute.
parenthetical.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

Winnings from gaming here is refers to winnings by the players from gaming, money paid to players as a result of gaming, winnings from what...
the players do.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

Th- they they could be regarded synonymous if both are used as nouns, Mr. Chief Justice, or both are used as adjectives.
two...

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: ask? Th- the- under your reading, what, using Justice Scalia's A and B, what function does A play?
What function A plays is that the tax is imposed on the winnings from gaming as a result of what the players have won.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

Not necessarily...
b-
because when you get to the second set, Your Honor, particularly sixty fifty I and chapter thirty-five, the text of those provisions have nothing to do with winnings.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: No.
Well...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: So, wouldn't that have been covered just as easily by simply saying concerning wagering operations?
Well, section fourteen forty-one and thirty-four oh two actually do impose a tax, a percentage of tax, that is on the winnings from gaming.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: That that's the chapter we're okay,
The chapter thirty-five...
i- is different, Your Honor.
Okay.
a cha- a tax on the operator based on the wagers that have been received, not the money that the operator has paid out.
All right.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Let me put it this way, and it's suggested by Justice Ginsburg's line of questioning.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: It is the only reason it makes sense.
Yes, sir.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, then that, it seems to me, destroys your argument because you you you you are, you want to say that gaming covers the entire universe of winnings that are subject to withholding.
I- If you would...
So, it seems to me that...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: des- that destroys the distinction you're trying to make which is what Justice Ginsburg's line of questioning, it seemed, suggested to me at least.
Wi- With respect, Your Honor, if you look at wagering and gaming as nouns, they could be read to refer to the same thing.
It has nothing...
to do with it.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: The oddity of the argument to me is that the, you're assum- I think your explanation is assuming that the basic activity that's going on in a casino, which is giving rise to each of these different kinds of liability, is the same activity.

right?

W Wi- With respect, Your Honor, if i- if the statute is read closely, the first three provisions of the parenthetical apply to concerning the reporting and withholding of taxes with respect to the winnings.

I I I I'm I'm not being clear here.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Mhm.
Nothing to do with reporting and withholding.
consistently, and the Government will concede that.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

That's correct. Yes, Your Honor.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

Other type of wagering operation,
Your Honor. That...

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

statute, Your Honor.

mean gaming...

this is...

But, counsel...

In Mescalero, Your Honor, there were actually two particular taxes at issue.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: There's a well recognized presumption, Mr. Luthey.
The underlying trust relationship, Your Honor, between the United States and the Indians, its wards, as recognized by this Court in the County of Oneida...
decision.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: but y- y- y- w- wh- g- give me a better reason than that.

Because the statute is imposed by Congress on its wards, and this Court has long recognized, including in the Montana versus Blackfeet Tribe, that statutes concerning Indians that have ambiguity are to be construed in favor of the Indians.
Mr. Luthey, no no...

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: you had your finger on your button before I did.

to that?
direct Your Honor to Squire versus Capoeman at three fifty-one US one where this Court dealt with a Federal tax, a claimed exemption from Federal taxation,

and applied the Indian canon in favor of the tax exemption sought by the Indians.

D- Do some tr-

text_blocks.text: may I a- ask you one question on on the text that supports Justice Breyer's notion that maybe this was just a crazy drafter? The sta- section starts out, the provisions of the Internal Revenue Code of nineteen eighty-six.

I I would suggest to Your Honor that the provisions of the Internal Revenue Code of nineteen eighty-six are then explained after the parenthetical by specifically what the provisions concern that are to be applied in the same way as States, and specifically included in that is chapter thirty-five which contains the exemption for States.
A- And in fact...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: the sentence then to start sections so and so and so and so concerning? Why have the provisions of the Internal Revenue Code?

I- The the the lead-in, the provisions of the Internal Revenue Code, is limited by its by the part of the statute that identifies what the internal revenue concerns that shall be applicable equally for State gaming, as well as for the tribal activity here.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Very well, Mr. Luthey.
Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court.

I'm always excited to appear before you, Your Honor.
It makes no...

Makes no reference,
and it does not, I should point out, exempt States from all taxes.

text_blocks.text: W- J- Just Just not just lotteries.

Is that in the papers before us?

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

be a foregone conclusion to many tribal lawyer-

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Is there someone over in the IRS whose job it is to look through bills, when they finally emerge, and check the cross references and the numbers who might have caught what seems to be, in your argument certainly, an accidental error in not taking a number out that should have been taken out? Is there anyone there whose job it is to do that? I would think there was.

a lot of people both at the IRS and on the Hill whose job it is to comb through tax legislation.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: May I now ask you to turn to to something else? I I asked counsel on the other side about the significance of your argument that the presumption favoring the the tribes in this situation should not operate, even though it might in a case of State taxation, because of the Government's plenary power over Indians as as distinct from the States' right only by sufferance of the Federal Government to tax.

I think because of the historical difference in the relations between the Federal Government and the tribes on the one hand and the State governments and the tribes on the other hand, and the best case I can point you to on that is the Kagama case from the end of the last century which talks about the trust relationship and it talks about the fact that the tribes stand in a very different relation to the Federal Government from the relation in which they stand to the...
States.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: that that certainly affects, we'll assume the obligation of the Government, and it certainly may well accept the m- the specific decisions that the Government makes.
I think there are...
two things that I'd l-

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: counterintuitive, I guess.
Well, there are two things I'd like to point out about that.
revenue statutes in a way that...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: tell us that in- informs us in in construction? It it tells us something about the Government's obligations to various groups of people, but I don't know what it tells us about about meaning.
I'm not sure it tells you very much at all about meaning.
construction for all the same reasons...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I'm assuming you got two tie-breakers and they're at odds.
for all the same reasons...
that the trust relationship exists in the first place...
Yes, but you say...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: they're a- they're at they're n- they're not or the the the the apparent loggerhead should should dissolve when you realize that the Government has a particular trust relationship to Indians.

I don't suggest that in in cases involving Federal taxation because there is an an equally strong and and, in this particular context, opposite principle that exemptions from the exactions, the general exactions, to support the Federal Government are to be narrowly construed.
And more more to the point,
they're not to be emp-
inferred.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: supposing we didn't have here an Indian tribe but an indi- individual Indian who was claiming exemption from taxation.
Not in the same not in the same way.
if I could, to the other reason...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: before we get off of canons, I w- we've just been talking about two, but there's a third one.
T- To be sure,

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: the Indians' proposed interpretation here is strained, but you can do it where whereas there is no possible way to read section thirty-five on your interpretation as being relevant.
Right.
ninety A of, yeah of the appendix...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: to the petition.
But page ninety A.
But...
I don't think it's just a strained reading, I think it's an impossible reading...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But you do concede that, a- as I believe Judge Dyke said, the only way you can make sense out of the statute is to treat it as though the reference to chapter thirty-five were not there.
I think that's right.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Maybe I can just ask you one clarifying question.
I'm sorry.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, the one we're talking about in the case.
The whole this whole tax...
or the ta- or the wagering tax?

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: The the wagering tax.

The wagering tax i- the definitions the n- the definitions on page ninety-seven A exempt from, they define define a l- a wager as sports wagering or forty-four twenty-one one C, any wager placed in a lottery conducted for profit.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: It does exclude...
them.
excludes those.
of the...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Of what?
Of the main gray brief, the gray brief on the merits.
That would have had to come up...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: through the Ways and Means Committee if they had done that?
I suspect it would have had to go through the tax writing...
committee certainly,
yes.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Thank you, Mr. DuMont.
Thank you, Your Honor.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Thank you, Mr. Luthey.
